resource.descriptiontext:
"The AWWA Free Water Audit Software (Audit Software) was first released in 2006, and has been through several generations. It includes a data-grading capability that allows the auditor to rate the overall degree of validity of their water audit data. Guidance on loss control planning is given based upon the credibility of the data and the measure of losses displayed by the water audit. The current version of the Audit Software is Version 5.0, published in 2014. Highlighted features of Version 5.0 include a visual dashboard for graphical display of non-revenue water components, a comments feature for capture of essential notes, and improved overall user experience.
The AWWA Water Audit Compiler (Compiler) was launched in 2011 and can be utilized to quickly assemble water audit data from multiple water utilities; allowing for comparisons of data across water utilities.
The Leakage Component Analysis (LCA) Model was developed to provide the water industry with a computer-based model for leakage component analysis, failure frequency analysis, economic leakage control intervention strategy evaluation, and display of key water loss performance indicators."
resource.commentstext: A complete water loss toolset. This is a good staring point for utilities large or small. Will require training via online tutorials. If the system has an Asset Management system in placed it may already have a water loss component.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: A series of software tools that users can use to review, compile, and analyze water audit data.

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
resource.descriptiontext: EPA's Benchmark Dose Software (BMDS) fits mathematical models to doe-response or exposure-response data. This software can help EPA risk assessors estimate the dose or exposure of a chemical or chemical mixture, with confidence limits, that is associated with a given response level. This dose or exposure estimate can be used as a benchmark for establishing guidelines that help protect against the adverse health effects associated with the chemical or chemical mixture.
resource.commentstext: Advanced tool to determine mathematical models on exposure data.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Software that can help EPA risk assessors estimate the dose of exposure of a chemical or chemical mixture, with confidence limits, that is associated with a given response level.
resource.topictext: Brownfields and Re-development and Industrial Cleanup

resource.resourcename: Check up program for small systems
resource.commentstext: A complete asset management system for small utilities, include inventory, O&M and finance forms to collect and report data in developing an AMP. The toolset includes training, the system and technical assistance. Updated annually and has been used by 1000s of utilities. Has been integrated into several state utility trainings.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Asset management tool for small drinking water and wastewater utilities. Provides simple comprehensive approach based off of EPA Simple Tools for Effective Performance.

resource.descriptiontext: This Climate and Disaster Risk Screening Tool provides a systematic way to undertake due diligence and flag potential risks for projects in the General sector. The tool guides the user through a simple step-by-step approach to identifying potential risks at an early stage of project design. Users can browse the tool by creating their own log-in username and password.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool that provides systematic way to undertake due diligence and flag potential risks for projects in the general sector.

resource.descriptiontext: The community Based Water Resiliency (CBWR) Tool is an easy way to find out how prepared your community is to handle emergencies that impact your water systems and learn about tools and resources that can be used to build resilience.
resource.commentstext: The self-assessment in the tool is for: Drinking water and wastewater utilities, state primacy agencies, hospitals, public health agencies, fire, police, emergency managers, elected officials, concerned citizens.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool to determine how prepared your community is to handle emergencies that impact your water systems and learn about tools and resources that can be used to build resilience.

resource.resourcename: Cost Evaluation of Point-of-Use and Point-of-Entry Treatment Units for Small Systems: Cost Estimating Tool and Users Guide
resource.descriptiontext: A companion tool to the Treatment Options Guide for modeling operations and maintenance (e.g., maintenance, monitoring, and public education) and capital costs (e.g., purchase, installation, and permitting).
resource.commentstext: Very focused on one treatment technology.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Companion tool to the Treatment Options Guide for modeling operations and maintenance and capital costs.

resource.resourcename: Discharge Monitoring Report (DMR) Pollutant Loading Tool
resource.descriptiontext: The Discharge Monitoring Report (DMR) Pollutant Loading Tool is designed to help you determineÂ who is discharging, what pollutants they are discharging and how much, and where they are discharging. The tool calculates pollutant loadings from permit and DMR data from EPA's Integrated Compliance Information System for the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (ICIS-NPDES).Â
resource.commentstext: Beneficial tool for discharge monitoring.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool designed to help determine who is discharging, what pollutants they are discharging, where they are discharging, and how much they are discharging.

resource.descriptiontext: Software that models the hydraulic and water quality behaviors of water distribution piping systems. Performs extended period simulation of water movement and quality behavior within pressurized pipe networks. EPANET tracks the flow of water in each pipe, the pressure at each node, the height of the water in each tank, the type of chemical concentration throughout the network during a simulation period, water age, source, and tracking.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Software that models hydraulic and water quality behaviors of water distribution piping systems.

resource.descriptiontext: The Water Research Foundation has developed a tool to help water and wastewater utilities evaluate their current and desired levels of performance related to the 10 attributes that were identified in the EPA report, Effective Utility Management: A Primer for Water and Wastewater Utilities (2008). The tool is aligned with the Primer, identifies practice areas used by the water sector to support each attribute, and provides a structured process benchmarking exercise to help water utilities conduct a self-assessment of any or all of the 10 attributes that they want to improve to meet their goals.
resource.commentstext: Good tool for KPI, especially for utilities that are not using an off the shelf Asset Management Tool.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool used to help water and wastewater utilities evaluate their current and desired levels of performance.

resource.resourcename: HEC-RAS Hydrologic Engineer Centers River Analysis System
resource.descriptiontext: Allows user to perform one dimensional steady flow, unsteady flow, sediment transport/mobile bed computations, and water temperature modeling. Specifically designed to support water resources management with water resource planning and management tools. Designed to perform a one-dimensional hydraulic calculations for a full network of natural and constructed channels.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Allow users to perform one dimensional steady flow, unsteady flow, sediment transport/mobile bed computations, and water temperature modeling.

resource.descriptiontext: Desktop application that estimates the annual amount of rainwater and frequency of runoff from a specific site anywhere in the United States (including Puerto Rico). Estimates are based on local soil conditions, land cover, and historic rainfall records. Designed to be used by anyone interested in reducing runoff from a property including site developers, landscape architects, urban planners, and homeowners.
resource.commentstext: Website provides training materials and information on the application. Calculator accesses several national databases that provide soil, topography, rainfall, and evaporation information for the chosen site.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Application that estimates the annual amount of rainwater and frequency of runoff from a specific site.

resource.resourcename: Open Data: U.S. Energy Information Administration
resource.descriptiontext: The U.S. Energy Information Administration is committed to enhancing the value of its free and open data by making it available through an Application Programming Interface (API) and open data tools to better serve our customers. The data in the API is also available in bulk file, in Excel via the add-in, and via widgets that embed interactive data vizualizations of EIA data on any website. By making EIA data available in machine-readable formats, the creativity in the private, the non-profit, and the public sectors can be harnessed to find new ways to innovate and create value-added services powered by public data.
resource.commentstext: API provided for a series of different data sets regarding energy consumption.

resource.descriptiontext: Program for predicating polluting particle passage through pits, puddles and ponds. This model predicts the generation and transport of stormwater runoff pollutants in urban watersheds. Continuous water-balance and mass-balance calculations are performed on a user-defined system consisting of the following elements: watersheds; devices; particle classes; water quality components.
resource.commentstext: May have compatibility issues.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Predicts polluting particle passage through pits, puddles and ponds.

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
resource.descriptiontext: The purpose of this tool is to prioritize your water distribution and transmission pipes for renewal projects. This prioritization will identify the set of pipes most at risk for failure and with the greatest cost-based consequences for inclusion in your capital improvement program (CIP).
resource.commentstext: Good tool for CIP, especially for utilities that are not using an off the shelf Asset Management Tool.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool used to prioritize water distribution and transmission pipes for renewal projects. Will identify the set of pipes most at risk for failure with a cost based assessment.

resource.descriptiontext:
"Water Utility Response On-The-Go is an innovative tool that consolidates information and tools that water utility operators and their response partners may need during an emergency. The tool is ideal for small systems that lack a large support network in place when natural disasters strike. Water Utility Response On-The-Go allows users to accomplish the following:
identify and contact emergency response partners monitor local and national severe weather conditions review and complete incident-specific checklists; and populate save and email both generic damage assessment forms and FEMA incident command system form."
resource.commentstext: New tool for mobile Emergency Preparedness. Great tool to help utilities ready for emergency situations and help meet water security requirements. This tool could be moved to the Emergency Management category as well.
resource.shortdescriptiontext:
"Water Utility Response On-The-Go is an innovative tool that consolidates information and tools that water utility operators and their response partners may need during an emergency. The tool is ideal for small systems that lack a large support network in place when natural disasters strike. Water Utility Response On-The-Go allows users to accomplish the following:
identify and contact emergency response partners monitor local and national severe weather conditions review and complete incident-specific checklists; and populate save and email both generic damage assessment forms and FEMA incident command system form"

resource.resourcename: Sanitary Sewer Overflow Analysis and Planning (SSOAP) Toolbox
resource.descriptiontext: Rainfall-derived infiltration and inflow (RDII) is the increased portion water flow in a sanitary sewer system that occurs during and after a rainfall as a source of operating problems in sanitary sewer systems. SSOAP toolbox is a suite of computer software tools used for the quantification of RDII and help capacity analysis and condition assessment of sanitary sewer systems. This toolbox includes the previous SWMM-5 for performing dynamic routing of flows through the sanitary sewer systems. Prediction methodology employed in the SSOAP toolbox offers an effective means to design a focused sewer condition assessment program and maximize success of field investigation efforts.
resource.commentstext: Determines RDII characteristics, prioritizes sewer sheds for sewer condition assessment, sewer rehabilitation, evaluates performance of sewer improvements, managing and analyzing flow monitoring and rainfall data.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: SSOAP toolbox is a suite of computer software tools used for the quantification of RDII and help capacity analysis and condition assessment of sanitary systems.

resource.resourcename: Security and Emergency Response Planning Toolbox for Small Water and Wastewater Systems
resource.commentstext: Good tool for utilities to run table top exercise. Maybe better as a web tool to allow sharing of results. Older tool and more focused on training. EPA Water Security tools seem to be better and more available/newer. This tool is very small system focused.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Toolbox that consists of five core modules in relation to security and emergency planning.

resource.descriptiontext: Allow citizens to connect with government. App allows local citizens to report possible disasters in order to get issues addressed quickly. Provides a series of reporting tools that are beneficial for analysis or potential problem areas. App connects governments and citizens in a quick and efficient fashion.
resource.commentstext: Reporting tool based on application to connect citizens with local government.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Application that allows local citizens to report possible disasters in order to get issues addressed quickly.

resource.resourcename: Source Water Protection Cost Benefit Analysis Tool
resource.descriptiontext: This tool is designed to assist you in evaluating the triple bottom-line costs and benefits of different source water protection options. Cost/benefit calculations help evaluate, prioritize, justify, and ultimately implement source water protection initiatives.
resource.commentstext: Although a useful tool not many small utilities conduct triple bottom line analysis on source water. But it is simple to use and relatively straightforward for most audience.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool used to evaluate the triple bottom-line costs and benefits of different source water protection options.

resource.descriptiontext: Used throughout world for planning, analysis and design related to Stormwater runoff, combined and sanitary sewers, and other drainage systems in urban areas. There are many applications for drainage systems in non-urban areas as well. Dynamic hydrology-hydraulic water quality simulation model. Used for single event or long-term simulation of runoff quantity and quality from primarily urban areas.
resource.commentstext: SWMM Climate Adjustment Tool allows future climate change projections to be incorporated into the Stormwater management model.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Planning, analysis, and design related to stormwater runoff, combined and sanitary sewers, and other drainage systems in urban areas.

resource.resourcename: System for Urban Stormwater Treatment and Analysis Integration (SUSTAIN)
resource.descriptiontext: A decision support system that assists stormwater management professionals with developing and implementing plans for flow and pollution control measures to protect source waters and meet water quality goals. SUSTAIN allows watershed and stormwater practitioners to develop, evaluate, and select optimal best management practice (BMP) combinations at various watershed scales based on cost and effectiveness.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Assists stormwater management professionals with developing and implementing plans for flow and pollution control measures to protect source waters and meet water quality goals.

resource.resourcename: Tabletop Exercise Tool for Water Systems (TTX Tool)
resource.descriptiontext:
"The PC-based Tabletop Exercise Tool for Water Systems: Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Climate Resiliency (TTX Tool) contains materials that assist those interested in planning and facilitating tabletop exercises that focus on water sector related issues.
This updated TTX Tool contains 15 scenarios that address an all-hazards approach to emergency preparedness and response. It addresses natural hazards and man-made incidents and introduces the potential impacts of climate change on the water sector."
resource.commentstext: Good tool for utilities to run table top exercise. Maybe better as a web tool to allow sharing of results. Older tool.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool that contains materials that assist in planning and facilitating tabletop exercises that focus on water sector related issues.

resource.descriptiontext: VSAT Version 6.0 complies with the water sector risk assessment standard and can offer liability protection under the Department of Homeland Security's Support Anti-Terrorism by Fostering Effective Technologies (SAFETY) Act program. EPA strongly encourages drinking water and wastewater utility owners and operators to use VSAT 6.0 to conduct or update an all-hazards risk assessment.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool that complies with the water sector risk assessment standard and can offer liability protection under the Department of Homeland Security.
resource.topictext: Drinking Water and Wastewater|Natural Disaster and Emergency Management

resource.resourcename: WAWTTAR (Water and Wastewater Treatment Technologies Appropriate for Reuse)
resource.descriptiontext: WAWTTAR is a predictive program intended to assist planners in selecting suitable water and wastewater treatment options appropriate to the material and manpower resources available to particular communities throughout the world. WAWTTAR is designed to assist in alleviating the problem of overlooking good processes alternatives for water and wastewater treatment, and also help screen out treatment technologies which are inappropriate for given locales and situations.
resource.commentstext: This would be a better tool if it was updated more frequently. Treatment options tools seem to be limited.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Predictive program to assist planners in selecting water and wastewater treatment options appropriate to the material and manpower resources available to particular communities through the world.

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
resource.descriptiontext: This calculator provides the user with a series of questions regarding soil, air, or tap water readings. It will require the user to have specific chemical data regarding these topics. The user will select a list of individual chemicals as well as their levels. The calculator will then provide the safe amount for all age levels.
resource.commentstext: User will need to have specific chemical information in order to retrieve active results. However, you are able to do a generic search of specific chemicals to see their levels of safety.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Calculator that provides user with a series of questions regarding soil, air, or tap water readings.
resource.topictext: Brownfields and Re-development and Industrial Cleanup

resource.descriptiontext: This model helps users interpret and predict water quality responses to natural phenomena and manmade pollution for various pollution management decisions. WASP is a dynamic compartment-modeling program for aquatic systems, including both the water column and the underlying benthos. WASP is one of the most widely used water quality models in the United States. Widely applied in the development of Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDL). Has capabilities of linking with hydrodynamic and watershed models which allows for multi-year analysis under varying meteorological and environmental conditions.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Interpret and predict water quality response to natural phenomena and manmade pollution for various pollution management decisions.

resource.resourcename: Water Utility Customer Assistance Program Cost Estimation Tool
resource.descriptiontext: This tool was developed to help utilities assess the costs and benefits of implementing a customer affordability program in their service area. Using information from the U.S. Census Bureau and water and wastewater rates inputted by the user, this interactive instrument incorporates information about the eligibility threshold to qualify for an affordability program, annual assistance offered per customer, percent of customers responsible for bad debt, among other fields.
resource.commentstext: Good tool for setting up rate programs for rural or low income areas. Simple to use.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool used to help utilities assess the costs and benefits of implementing a customer affordability program in their service area.

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
resource.descriptiontext: Map out your customizable project and receive basic capacity, energy yield, revenue and system displacement data. Map site, plot site, configure set, and analyze the site data. The tool provides a basic tool as well as an advanced tool. Each tool requires the user to log in.
resource.commentstext: Tool provides a great deal of information on the possibility of using solar for particular locations. Tool allows the use to select locations.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Map customizable project with results on basic capacity, energy yield, revenue and system displacement data.

resource.descriptiontext: Data related to climate change that can help inform and prepare America's communities, businesses, and citizens. You can currently find data and resources related to costal flooding, food resilience, water, ecosystem vulnerability human health, energy infrastructure transportation and the artic region. Over time you will be able to find additional data and tools relevant to other important climate-related impacts.
resource.commentstext: Data base search with a map to help narrow search results for Climate Change.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Data related to climate change that can inform and prepare communities, business, and citizens.

resource.descriptiontext: Know your H20 is a free application available on the iTunes and Android App stores. Know Your H2O? helps you to identify the existing and historic environmental hazards in your community. They are working with a national environmental database search company to offer a report to help you understand your homeÃ¢Â€Â™s or your future homes environmental health status within a community. They are doing this by taking a snapshot of the current and historic environmental concerns and hazards in the community and a review of select criminal activity.
resource.commentstext: Application is free. Requires a smart phone. Know Your H2O? is an educational tool that can help you diagnose the problem with your water. This app will lead you through a series of questions to pinpoint the issues with your water. You can reach your diagnosis through describing symptoms that are effecting your home, your health, or the water itself. Once you receive your diagnosis result(s), the app is designed to educate you by displaying full lists of symptoms, causes, and solutions, as well as links to other educational sources. The app will then show you various testing kit options specifically designed to treat those results. If the problem is more extensive and in depth testing is required, Know Your H2O? will also connect you with featured local professionals.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Mobile application that helps users identify the existing and historic environmental hazards in your community.

resource.descriptiontext: A simple form builder for mobile devices to allow users to manage and create forms for inspections and other utility data collection.
resource.commentstext: Only include as an example of a free mobile form builder that utilities could use to build inspection or O&M forms. This can be used by utilities to build forms or websites. We can include more of these technologies if this seems relevant.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: A simple form builder for mobile devices to allow users to manage and create forms for inspections and other utility data collection.

resource.descriptiontext: Apple App for mobile devices. This application is ideal for Users of all ages where they can learn about water quality parameters such as Dissolved Oxygen, E. coli, pH, Nutrients, Turbidity and much more. Students can gather data about their field study site in a site profile. The Benthic Macro invertebrates section acts as a field guide of all of the major taxa used to calculate pollution tolerance indexes. Pictures, sketches and descriptions for identification are included for twenty-two macro invertebrates. Scientists and citizen science groups can use the Water Quality app to learn about water quality parameters and to collect chemical and biological data from their study sites. Data is organized in reports and can be printed or submitted to the River on the Web database.
resource.commentstext: This application is a pay to use application. It costs $4.99 on the iTunes Application store.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Mobile application that informs users about water quality parameters such as dissolved oxygen, E. Coli, pH, nutrients, turbidity, and much more.

resource.resourcename: EPAS Composite Model for Leachate Migration with Transformation Products
resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OLEM - Office of Land and Emergency Management
resource.descriptiontext: EPACMTP (EPA's Composite Model for Leachate Migration with Transformation Products) version 2.0 is a subsurface fate and transport model used by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to simulate the impact of the release of constituents present in waste that is managed in land-based waste mangement units. EPACMTP simulates fate and transport in both the unsaturated zone and the saturated zone (ground water) using the advective-dispersive equation with terms to account for equilibrium sorption and first-order transformation. The Model simulates the migration of a chemical constituent vertically downward from the base of a waste management unit through the unsaturated zone until it reachs the water table. As the leachate enters the ground water, it will mix with ambient ground water (which is assumed to be free of pollutants) and a contaminant plume, which extends in the direction of downgradient ground-water flow, will develop. EPACMTP accounts for the spreading of the plume in
resource.commentstext: .exe file. Requires knowledge, but useful tool.
resource.sourcesystemtext: Registry of EPA Applications and Databases

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OLEM / ORCR / MISWD - Municipal and Industrial Solid Waste Division
resource.descriptiontext: The IWAIR model was developed by EPA for use in evaluating inhalation risks. Using limited site-specific information, IWAIR can estimate whether specific wastes and management practices may pose an unacceptable risk to human health. IWAIR consists of three components: an emissions model, a dispersion model to determine ambient air concentrations at specified receptor locations; and a risk model to calculate either the risk to exposed individuals or waste constituent concentrations in the waste management unit. This model, along with IWEM, are companion tools associated with The Guide to Industrial Waste Management (EPA530-99-001).
resource.commentstext: .exe file. Requires knowledge, but useful tool.
resource.keywordstext: OSWER, ORCR, solid waste, industrial waste, non-hazardous
resource.sourcesystemtext: Registry of EPA Applications and Databases

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OLEM / ORCR / MISWD - Municipal and Industrial Solid Waste Division
resource.descriptiontext: The IWEM software helps industrial waste facility managers (or beneficial users) determine the most appropriate waste management unit design(or the appropriateness of beneficially reusing industrial materials) by evaluating one or more types of liners, the hydrologic conditions of the site, and the toxicity and expected leachate concentrations of the anticipated waste constituents. This information allows managers to determine minimum liner requirements required to protect ground water or determine whether the beneficial use of industrial materials is appropriate or not.
resource.commentstext: .exe file. Requires knowledge, but useful tool.
resource.keywordstext: OSWER, OSW, municipal solid waste, waste management, landfil
resource.sourcesystemtext: Registry of EPA Applications and Databases

resource.descriptiontext: The intent of this document is to establish better quality indoor air in the building after construction and during occupancy. Conduct baseline IAQ testing using protocols consistent with the methods listed in Table 1 for all occupied spaces. Use current versions of ASTM standard methods, EPA compendium methods, or ISO methods, as indicated.
resource.commentstext: LEED certified, or knowledgeable professionals will need to use this tool. Helps assess indoor air quality.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource to establish better indoor air quality in a building after construction as well as during occupancy.

resource.descriptiontext: SolarRating Online uses information collected from over 1000 weather stations worldwide to assess the suitability of your home for solar technologies: photovoltaic (PV) to generate electricity and solar thermal for heating domestic hot water.
resource.commentstext: Assessment tool provides basic information relating to your location and roof angles on solar energy capacity.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool that uses data to determine the suitability of a home for solar technologies.

resource.resourcename: 10 Shocking Facts about Indoor Air Quality
resource.descriptiontext: List of facts regarding indoor air quality.
resource.commentstext: Easy to read factsheet. Provides a list of information regarding indoor air quality.

resource.descriptiontext: This free tool is designed to help utilities assess their Stage 2 DBP compliance situation, and help them evaluate applicable DBP reduction strategies.
resource.commentstext: Provides an easy to follow tool and guidance on the rule.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool designed to help utilities assess their Stage 2 DBP compliance situation, and help evaluate applicable DBP reduction strategies.

resource.resourcename: 5 Star Wetland and UrbanWater Restoration Grants
resource.descriptiontext: The Five Star and Urban Waters Restoration Program brings together students, conservation corps, other youth groups, citizen groups, corporations, landowners and government agencies to provide environmental education and training through projects that restore wetlands and streams.
resource.commentstext: Grants for webtland and urban waters.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Provides environmental education and training through projects that restore wetlands and streams.

resource.resourcename: A students guide to Global Climate Change
resource.descriptiontext: Basic tools for students.
resource.commentstext: Highly recommended for students.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Basic tools for students.

resource.descriptiontext: Ask WATERS answers multi-program questions that draw on information from the databases linked through WATERS. This tool generates cross-program calculations, examines spatial relationships between programs, performs nationwide analyses, produces multi-program inventory reports for a given geographic area, and investigates interstate water quality issues.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool that answers multi-program questions that draw on information from the databases linked through WATERS.

resource.resourcename: AWWA Online Free Learning Courses for Small Systems
resource.descriptiontext:
"FREE technical, financial and managerial training and assistance is available through a US Environmental Protection Agency Grant and AWWAs training partners, the Rural Community Assistance Partnership (RCAP) and the Environmental Finance Center Network (EFCN). AWWA membership is not required, and in-person and online training is available through 2015. Training is designed to help small public water systems maintain compliance with the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA). Training includes online tutorials and in person assistance.
This eLearning course for financial sustainability focuses on 3 major areas needed by small systems to achieve financial sustainability; including understanding enterprise funds and their revenues, as well as an overview of what is needed to protect public health through safe water."
resource.accesscommentstext:
Financial Sustainability for Small Systems (eLearning) - http://www.awwa.org/store/productdetail.aspx?productid=53117011
Maintaining and Achieving RTCR Compliance for Small Systems - http://www.awwa.org/store/productdetail.aspx?productid=48406119
2015 Small Systems Training - http://www.awwa.org/resources-tools/water-knowledge/small-systems/2015-small-systems-training.aspx
resource.commentstext: Not a tool but a set of training modules used that can be available to utilities.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: eLearning course for financial sustainability that will provide an overview of what is needed to protect health through safe water.

resource.resourcename: About the Office of Land and Emergency Management
resource.descriptiontext: The Office of Land and Emergency Management provides policy, guidance and direction for the Agency's emergency response and waste programs. We develop guidelines for the land disposal of hazardous waste and underground storage tanks. We provide technical assistance to all levels of government to establish safe practices in waste management.
resource.commentstext: Basic Information about the office.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Policy guidance and direction for the emergency response and waste programs.

resource.resourcename: Access Climate Resources for Water Utilities
resource.descriptiontext: A series of information, studies, and reports that are tailored specifically for water utilities. This resource provides water utilities with tools, training, and technical assistance needed to adapt to climate change. Some tools included are: Scenario planning to support decision making, CRWU 101 Introduction, Climate Change and Water Sector, Adaptation Strategies Guide, as well as various studies and reports.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that provides water utilities with tools, training, and technical assistance needed to adapt to climate change.

resource.resourcename: Advanced Manufacturing Office: Office of Energy Efficiency & Renewable Energy
resource.descriptiontext: Partner with industry, small business, universities, regional entities, and other stakeholders to identify and invest in emerging clean energy technologies. We establish collaborative communities focused on developing and commercializing targeted technologies; play a leadership role in the national inter-agency Advanced Manufacturing Partnership; and encourage a culture of continuous improvement in corporate energy management.
resource.commentstext: The Advanced Manufacturing Office (AMO) provides cost-shared funding to pursue innovative technology R&D and increase energy efficiency across the manufacturing sector.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resources that provides information on partnering with industry, small business universities, regional entities, and other stakeholders to identify and invest in clean energy.

resource.resourcename: Advanced Technology: Environmental and Energy Center
resource.descriptiontext: A resource for business, education, and government. Provides a series of materials, training's, resources in regards to emerging environmental technologies.
resource.commentstext: Provides a series of different resources, guidance, training for emerging environmental technology.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: A resource for business, education, and government. Provides a series of materials, training's, resources in regards to emerging environmental technologies.
resource.sourcesystemtext: Advanced Technology Environmental and Energy Center

resource.resourcename: Advancing Sustainable Materials Management: Facts and Figures
resource.descriptiontext: Each year EPA produces a report called Advancing Sustainable Materials Management: Facts and Figures, formerly called Municipal Solid Waste in the United States: Facts and Figures. It includes information on municipal solid waste (MSW) generation, recycling, and disposal. The 2013 report provides additional information on source reduction (waste prevention) of MSW, information on historical tipping fees for MSW, and information on the Construction and Demolition Debris generation, which is outside of the scope of MSW.
resource.commentstext: Provides a list of facts and resources for advancing sustainable materials management.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Facts and figures that includes information on municipal solid waste generation, recycling, and disposal.

resource.descriptiontext: The Air Data website gives you access to air quality data collected at outdoor monitors across the United States, Puerto Rico, and the U. S. Virgin Islands. The data comes primarily from the AQS (Air Quality System) database. You can choose from several ways of looking at the data.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Air quality data collected at outdoor monitors across the United States.

resource.descriptiontext: To improve air quality, it is important for governments, industry and the public to understand the interconnected components of an air quality management system. This Web site describes each of these components and provides links to a tremendous amount of additional information, tools and resources provided on other EPA and non-EPA web sites.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Website that provides resources to understand air quality management systems.

resource.descriptiontext: Information on requirements for Animal Feeding Operations.
resource.commentstext: Information regarding AFO and how to handle with stormwater management.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Information on requirements for Animal Feeding Operations.

resource.descriptiontext: These grants are provided to eligible entities, including nonprofit organizations, to develop environmental programs that recruit, train, and place unemployed and under-employed residents of communities affected by brownfields and other environmental contaminants with the skills needed to secure full-time, sustainable employment in the environmental field and in assessment and cleanup work taking place in their communities. Each Environmental Workforce Development and Job Training (EWDJT) grant may be funded up to $200,000 over a three year period.Â‚Â
resource.commentstext: Funding opportunities.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Grants to develop environmental programs that recruit, train, and place unemployed and under employed residents of communities affected by brownfields or other environmental contaminants.
resource.topictext: Brownfields and Re-development and Industrial Cleanup|Finance and Grants

resource.descriptiontext: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) created the Beach Advisory and Closing Online Notification (BEACON) system to meet the Agency's requirement to provide to the public a database of pollution occurrences for coastal recreation waters. EPA's response to this requirement, BEACON, contains state-reported beach monitoring and notification data. EPA recently updated BEACON to include several enhancements and has named the new system BEACON 2.0.
resource.commentstext: Provides an easy to use map where individuals may search the costal health of their beaches. Any spills or issues should be reported here on a fairly frequent basis.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Provides a public database of pollution occurrences for coastal recreation waters.

resource.resourcename: Being Prepared for Climate Change Workbook for Developing Risk-Based Adaptations Plans
resource.descriptiontext: "The Being Prepared..." workbook and the associated resources guide users to develop a risk-based climate change adaptation plan consisting of a vulnerability assessment and an action plan to reduce the most pressing risks. This Workbook presents a guide to climate change adaptation planning based on EPAs experience with watershed management, the National Estuary Program and the Climate Ready Estuaries program. The Workbook will assist organizations that manage environmental resources to prepare a broad, risk-based adaptation plan.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource to develop risk-based climate change adaptation plan consisting of vulnerability assessment and an action plan to reduce most pressing risks.

resource.resourcename: Better Assessment Science Integrating Point and Nonpoint Sources (BASINS)
resource.descriptiontext: BASINS is a multipurpose environmental analysis system designed to help regional, state, and local agencies perform watershed and water quality based studies.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: BASINS is a multipurpose environmental analysis system designed to help regional, state, and local agencies perform watershed and water quality based studies.

resource.descriptiontext: An Educational Primer on Sustainable Water Infrastructure Asset Management. As interest in water and wastewater asset management among utilities has grown over the past decade, a number of professional and government organizations have attempted to define asset management and develop strategic plans in an effort to focus the practice and implementation of asset management. This site synthesizes these initiatives to develop an educational primer for water and wastewater utility infrastructure asset management.
resource.commentstext: Training tool that is not updated very often.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Website develops an educational primer for water and wastewater utility infrastructure asset management.

resource.descriptiontext: The resource database is intended to provide users with a thorough listing of the government agencies, regional and national non-profits, community groups and businesses working on brownfields-related issues in their state and region. This database includes local, state, and federal government offices and programs; businesses; insurers; environmental consultants; web-based resources; community groups; community development corporations; associations; national organizations; and regional organizations.
resource.commentstext: Users are allowed to select a variety of criteria first starting with state. A series of organizations are then queried in order to improve search results.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Database that provides a listing of the government agencies, regional and national non-profits, community groups, and businesses working on brownfield related issues.

resource.descriptiontext: The TAB program funds technical assistance to communities and other stakeholders on brownfields issues with the goal of increasing the community's understanding and involvement in brownfield cleanup and revitalization, and helping to move brownfields sites forward toward cleanup and reuse. The TAB grantees funded through the TAB program, among other things, serve as an independent resource assisting communities with community involvement, better understanding the health impacts of brownfield sites, science and technology relating to brownfield site assessment, remediation, and site preparation activities, brownfield finance questions, information on integrated approaches to brownfield cleanup and redevelopment, facilitating stakeholder involvement, identifying sources of brownfields assessment and cleanup funding, understanding and complying with state brownfields and voluntary cleanup program requirements, and facilitating redevelopment activities.
resource.commentstext: TAB provides funding to organizations who have experience with providing technical assistance to communities and other stakeholders.

resource.resourcename: Carbon Pollution Standards for New, Modified, and Reconstructed Power Plants
resource.descriptiontext: Carbon Pollution Standards for New, Modified and Reconstructed Power Plants apply to brand new sources built in the future or to an existing unit that meets certain, specific conditions described in the Clean Air Act and implementing regulations for being modified or reconstructed.
resource.commentstext: Regulatory requirements.

resource.resourcename: Catalog of Federal Funding Sources for Watershed Protection
resource.descriptiontext: The Catalog of Federal Funding Sources for Watershed Protection Web site is a searchable database of financial assistance sources (grants, loans, cost-sharing) available to fund a variety of watershed protection projects. To select funding programs for particular requirements, use the search. You can use subject matter criteria based searches, or general word based searches of the funding programs, or both. Criteria searches include the type of organization (e.g., non-profit groups, private landowner, state, business), type of assistance sought (grants or loans), and keywords (e.g., agriculture, wildlife habitat).
resource.commentstext: Easy to use and search based on predefined set criteria.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Searchable database of financial assistance sources that are available to fund a variety of watershed protection projects.

resource.descriptiontext: In the final Clean Power Plan, the EPA provided a Clean Energy Incentive Program -- a program that states may use at their own option to incentivize early investments in wind and solar power generation, as well as in energy efficiency measures in low-income communities. State participation in the CEIP is optional; however, a state interested in participating in the CEIP must make a (non-binding) expression of its intent to participate in the CEIP in its plan or initial submittal due on September 6, 2016.
resource.commentstext: Program used to uincentivize early investments in wind and solar power.

resource.resourcename: Clean Power Plan For Existing Power Plants
resource.descriptiontext: Shaped by years of unprecedented outreach and public engagement, the final Clean Power Plan is fair, flexible and designed to strengthen the fast-growing trend toward cleaner and lower-polluting American energy. With strong but achievable standards for power plants, and customized goals for states to cut the carbon pollution that is driving climate change, the Clean Power Plan provides national consistency, accountability and a level playing field while reflecting each state energy mix.
resource.commentstext: Regulatory requirements.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that provides information on the Clean Power Plan that is designed to strengthen the fast growing trend toward cleaner and lower polluting American energy.

resource.resourcename: Clean Power Plan State-Specific Fact Sheets
resource.descriptiontext: State-specific fact sheets are provided below for 47 states (not including Alaska, Hawaii or Vermont). Each fact sheet includes the state interim and final carbon dioxide emission performance goals (expressed in both rate and mass), and how the rate-based goals compare to proposed goals. The state goals are designed to be met as part of the grid and over time, reflecting the inherent flexibility in the way the power system operates and the variety of ways in which the electricity system can deliver a broad range of opportunities for compliance for power plants and states.
resource.commentstext: Help states to determine most cost-effective approach to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: State specific fact sheets that are provided for 47 states, which includes carbon dioxide emission performance goals.

resource.resourcename: Clean Power Plan Toolbox for States
resource.descriptiontext: As co-regulators, states will develop plans to meet the guidelines in theÃ‚Â Clean Power Plan (CPP). The federalÃ‚Â resources provide information on state plan development and can help states determine the most cost-effective approaches to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector. Please note that inclusion of a measure in the toolbox does not mean that a state plan must include that measure. In addition, inclusion of these measures does not necessarily imply the approvability of an approach or method for use in a state plan. States will need to demonstrate that any measure included in a state plan meets all relevant criteria and adequately addresses elements of the plan components.Ã‚Â Please check this page for frequent updates. Ã‚Â
resource.commentstext: Help states to determine most cost-effective approach to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Provides information on state plan development and can assist in determining the most cost-effective approaches to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector.

resource.resourcename: Clean Water Act Laws, Regulations, Executive Orders
resource.descriptiontext: The Clean Water Act (CWA) establishes the basic structure for regulating discharges of pollutants into the waters of the United States and regulating quality standards for surface waters. The basis of the CWA was enacted in 1948 and was called the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, but the Act was significantly reorganized and expanded in 1972. "Clean Water Act" became the Act's common name with amendments in 1972.
resource.commentstext: List of Laws and Regulations.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that provides information on the Clean Water Act.

resource.resourcename: Climate Ready Water Utilities (CRWU) Storm Surge Map
resource.descriptiontext: Interactive map that shows storm surge of costal communities. This map illustrates hurricane strike frequency and worst-case coastal storm surge or inundation scenarios derived from the National Hurricane strike dataset. Federal Emergency Management Agency's 100-year and 500-year flood plains. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Sea, Lake, and Overland Surge from Hurricanes (SLOSH) model.
resource.commentstext: Easy to use map. Social media features. Series of filters to customize map.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Interactive map that shows storm surge of coastal communities.

resource.descriptiontext: This risk assessment tool allows water utilities to evaluate potential impacts of climate change. You can also identify adaptation options to address impacts using both traditional risk assessment and scenario-based methods. CREAT provides: - Lists of drinking water and wastewater utility assets (such as water resources, treatment plants, and pump stations) that climate change could impact - Possible climate change-related threats (such as flooding, drought, and water quality) - Adaptive measures that utilities can implement to reduce potential impacts
resource.commentstext: Good starting tool for testing impact of climate change scenarios. Nothing as comprehensive as HAZUS but a good tool for small utilities. Is updated and maintained by Water Security Division.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Risk assessment tool allows water utilities to evaluate potential impacts of climate change.

resource.descriptiontext: EPA's criminal enforcement program was established in 1982 and was granted full law enforcement authority by Congress in 1988. It enforces the nation's laws by investigating cases, collecting evidence, conducting forensic analyses and providing legal guidance to assist in the prosecution of criminal conduct that threatens people's health and the environment.Â
resource.commentstext: Criminal enforcement resource.

resource.descriptiontext: The purpose of this tool is to collect municipal solid waste data in a consistent manner to serve the following purposes: Facilitate the development of municipal solid waste master plans for cities, facilitate the preparation and implementation of investment projects, including those using Result-based financing (RBF) approaches, and exploring the potential for reducing short-lived climate pollutants(SLCP) emissions from the municipal solid waste sector.
resource.commentstext: Download excel document.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool to collect municipal solid waste data in a consistent manner to facilitate a implementation of investment projects, master plans, and more resources.

resource.descriptiontext: As the number of drinking water regulations has grown, EPA, states, and other organizations have committed to providing technical, managerial, and financial assistance to help your water system provide safe, high-quality drinking water. Use the link to access publications and other key information on the regulations that may apply to your water system. In addition, we have included the Compliance Guidance Under The Safe Drinking Water Act website that provides links to each regulation, training materials and decision trees on whether you are required to submit under each regulation.
resource.commentstext: Website provides reference to all of EPA's Water Supply Regs and gives a starting point. If additional information is needed we could pull out specific regs and link to them. This data could be put into a decision tree similar.

"The program also emphasizes providing funds to small and disadvantaged communities and to programs that encourage pollution prevention as a tool for ensuring safe drinking water.
The Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF) program is a federal-state partnership that provides communities a permanent, independent source of low-cost financing for a wide range of water quality infrastructure projects."

resource.descriptiontext: EPAÂ funds climate change research grants to improve knowledge of the health and environment effects of climate change, and provide sustainable solutions for communities to effectively manage and reduce the impacts of a changing climate. Some research topics include: Investigating the impact of climate change on air pollution gases and particles, water quality and ecosystems. Understanding the underlying factors contributing to changes air pollution and water quality. Using modeling tools to better understand the impacts of extreme events on air and water quality as well as provide better modeling tools to predict air, water and ecosystem characteristics under a changing climate.
resource.commentstext: List of grants relating to climate change. User is able to use search features as well to search for specific topics.

resource.descriptiontext: When a hazardous substance release or oil spill is reported, EPA may perform a variety of emergency response actions. This is done through EPA's 10 regional offices and in close cooperation with a network of federal, state, and local governments.

resource.resourcename: EPAs Interactive Sampling Guide for Drinking Water System Operators
resource.descriptiontext: PA has developed this new interactive CD-ROM and web site as part of our ongoing public drinking water sustainable infrastructure efforts. The purpose of this guide is to help drinking water system owners and operators better understand the general procedures involved in collecting Safe Drinking Water Act compliance samples. Additional sample shipping suggestions, sample tips, and sample requirements are made available within the body of this interactive guide.
resource.commentstext: I have not used this tool before but it provides help on how to sample and a simple step by step decision tree guidance.

resource.descriptiontext:
"Building on the success of the original EUM framework, EPA and USDA have developed two new document to help managers of rural and small water and wastewater systems effectively manage their operations. The first document is the Rural and Small Systems Guidebook to Sustainable Utility Management. The Guidebook uses the same EUM framework to help small systems assess their operations and develop a work plan for improving their performance.
Accompanying the Guidebook is the Workshop in a Box which contains materials to help systems and technical assistance providers work with systems using the Guidebook."
resource.commentstext: Primarily guidance and not really a tool. Would be good to have the information available in a tool but on its own it is a guidance document and rather long.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Documents developed to help managers of rural and small water and wastewater systems to effectively manage operations.

resource.descriptiontext: The Emergency Operations Center (EOC) serves as EPA's emergency response operational focal point. It is a communication and coordination hub designed to increase data management and coordination capabilities. The EOC provides support for Watch Officer communications, communications with the US Department of Homeland Security and other federal agencies, and links to regional and field assets. Capabilities Include: Video Conferencing, Audio Teleconferencing, Data analysis and modeling, secure information management.
resource.commentstext: Recommended in times of emergency.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that serves as EPA's emergency response operational focal point. A communication and coordination hub designed to increase data management.

resource.resourcename: Leak Detection and Repair: A Best Practices Guide
resource.descriptiontext: Leaking equipment, such as valves, pumps, and connectors, are a large source of emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and volatile hazardous air pollutants (VHAPs) The Leak Detection and Repair: A Best Practices GuideÂ‚Â - is intended for use by regulated entities, such as petroleum refineries and chemical manufacturing facilities, as well as compliance inspectors. The guide details some of the problems identified with leak detection and repair (LDAR) programs. It focuses on Method 21 requirements, and describes the practices that can be used to increase the effectiveness of an LDAR program.
resource.commentstext: Beneficial tool for operators and managers.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Best practices guide for leak detection and repair.

resource.resourcename: Moving Toward Sustainability: Sustainable and Effective Practices
resource.descriptiontext: EPA is now issuing Moving Toward Sustainability: Sustainable and Effective Practices for Creating Your Own Water Utility Roadmap. The purposes of this document is to assist utilities move toward sustainability by implementing proven practices over time at a pace consistent with their needs and the needs of the communities they serve. The document includes checklists and recommendations on moving towards sustainability.
resource.commentstext: Although a guidance document it is very easy to read and follow and address new topics and ways a small/medium/large utility can move into the 21st century. Great step by step process. Might be an interesting tool that could help work like Equifax or other scoring scenarios to show if you do this your utility can become more sustainable and improve operations and compliance.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that provides assistance and information on sustainable and effective practices for creating a water utility road map.

resource.descriptiontext: MyWATERS Mapper dynamically displays snapshots of EPA Office of Water program data. This version of MyWATERS Mapper depicts the status of NPDES permits for each State; summary information from the Clean Watershed Needs Survey; and water quality assessments. Future versions will include other Office of Water Program Snapshots. MyWATERS Mapper also contains water-related geographic themes such as 12-digit watersheds, the national stream network known as the National Hydrography Dataset, and other water-related map layers. MyWATERS Mapper enables you to create customized maps at national and local scales.
resource.commentstext: Requires shockwave in order to operate.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Dynamically displays snapshots of EPA Office of Water program data.

resource.descriptiontext: Contains basic information on the major features and elements of the NPDES permit program. The information in this section will be most useful to state and tribal officials, interested citizens, and others with an interest in the details of the NPDES program. This information is broadly applicable to all NPDES permits and programs, including concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs), pesticide discharges, combined sewer overflows (CSOs), pretreatment, sanitary sewer overflows (SSOs), stormwater and whole effluent toxicity (WET).

resource.resourcename: National Air Quality Site Assessment Tool
resource.descriptiontext: The National Air Quality Site Assessment Tool (NAQSAT) has been developed for the voluntary use of livestock producers and their advisors or consultants. It is intended to provide assistance to livestock and poultry producers in determining the areas in their operations where there are opportunities to make changes that result in reduced air emissions. Air emissions research from livestock production systems is increasing every year. NAQSAT is based on the most accurate, credible data currently available regarding mitigation strategies for air emissions of ammonia, methane, volatile organic compounds, hydrogen sulfide, particulates, and odor.
resource.commentstext: Will be valuable for specific rural communities.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool developed for the voluntary use of livestock producers and their advisors to provide assistance to producers in determining areas in the operations where they can reduce air emissions.

resource.resourcename: National Environmental Services Center Drinking Water and Wastewater Financial Assistance, Tools, Database and Technical Assistance
resource.descriptiontext: For over 35 years, the National Environmental Services Center (NESC) has helped thousands of small, rural communities with their drinking water, wastewater, environmental training, infrastructure resilience, and utility management needs--leading them to solutions to the problems they face. The site includes technical assistance phone numbers and ask the experts email and phone number. In addition it includes 2 listservs for drinking and wastewater. The site has migrated to Facebook and can be found at https://www.facebook.com/NationalEnvironmentalServicesCenter
resource.commentstext: This is a large website that provides numerous resources. The site has most recently moved to updating via Facebook. Much of the site material is outdated and they are most focused on technical assistance vs tool development.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Provides a vast number of different resources to communities in order to better understand and manage the drinking water and wastewater issues of today.

resource.resourcename: National Oil and Hazardous Substance Contingency Plan (NCP) Overview.
resource.descriptiontext: The National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan, more commonly called the National Contingency Plan or NCP, is the federal government's blueprint for responding to both oil spills and hazardous substance releases. The NCP is the result of efforts to develop a national response capability and promote coordination among the hierarchy of responders and contingency plans.
resource.commentstext: Overview discussing spills and information.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Federal government's blueprint for responding to both oil and hazardous substance spills.

resource.descriptiontext: The National Response System (NRS) routinely and effectively responds to a wide range of oil and hazardous substance releases. It is a multi-layered system of individuals and teams from local, state, and federal agencies, industry, and other organizations. These groups share expertise and resources to ensure that cleanup activities are timely, efficient, and minimize threats to human health and the environment.
resource.commentstext: Recommended in times of emergency.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that responds to a wide range of oil and hazardous substance releases.

resource.descriptiontext: Resource that provides information on a variety different types of disasters that may occur. Drought, earthquakes, heat, floods, hurricanes, landslides, and weather.

resource.descriptiontext: Traditionally, air pollution is measured by expensive, stationary and complex air-monitoring instrumentation. Only a few organizations, like federal, state and some industries, typically collect data of such high quality. Even so, this limits the amount of environmental monitoring data that is often available for exposure and health assessments. As air quality management problems become more complex, there is a need for enhanced air quality and exposure monitoring capabilities.
resource.commentstext: Informational, EPA, Education
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Provides research and information on air quality management problems as well as next generation measuring techniques.

resource.descriptiontext: This publication answers common questions about indoor air pollutants and discusses ways to reduce or eliminate the problems. To collect the data, monitoring equipment is needed and ranges in price from ten dollar sensors up to professional grade equipment costing tens of thousands of dollars.Â EPA's Next Generation Air Measuring siteÂ has an array of information on emerging technologies for air monitoring.

resource.resourcename: Reducing Global Health Risks through Mitigation of Short-Lived Climate Pollutants: Scoping Report for Policymakers
resource.descriptiontext: Short-lived climate pollutants (SLCPs), including black carbon, methane, and ozone, are responsible for a substantial fraction of climate change as well as for a significant proportion of air-pollution related deaths and diseases that kill some 7 million people per year.
resource.commentstext: Publication

resource.descriptiontext: The Clean Air Act is a statute written by Congress that gives EPA the authority to establish regulations, policy, and guidance to protect air quality. This page provides links to some of EPA's air pollution rules and regulations.

resource.resourcename: Renewable Energy Ready Home Solar Site Assessment Tool
resource.descriptiontext: The Renewable Energy Ready Home Solar Site Assessment Tool is intended to guide home builders in assessing whether a new home has the proper physical orientation to support a future installation of a solar energy system. This tool evaluates the proposed site's solar resource potential based on a series of known factors about the home at the time of construction, such as the home's location and anticipated shading effects at the proposed site. New homes that are found to provide a suitable installation environment are considered good candidates to be outfitted by the builder with the structural and system components needed to support the cost effective installation of a future renewable energy system.
resource.commentstext: Assessment tool provides basic information relating to your location and roof angles on solar energy capacity.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool intended to guide home builders in assessing whether a new home has the proper physical orientation to support a future installation of a solar energy system.

resource.resourcename: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Orientation Manual
resource.descriptiontext: This manual provides introductory information on the solid and hazardous waste management programs under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). Designed for EPA and state staff, members of the regulated community, and the general public who wish to better understand RCRA, this document constitutes a review of the RCRA program and is not a substitute for RCRA or its implementing regulations.
resource.commentstext: manual/document for RCRA Orientation.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Manual that provides introductory information on the solid and hazardous waste management programs under RCRA.

resource.descriptiontext: EPA is one of 11 federal agencies that participate in the SBIR Program established by the Small Business Innovation Development Act of 1982. EPA issues annual solicitations for Phase I and Phase II research proposals from science and technology-based firms. Phase II contracts are limited to small businesses that have successfully completed their Phase I projects. Provides funding for innovative business ideas in relation to the environment.
resource.commentstext: Funding opportunities for research/innovation.

resource.descriptiontext: Smart growth helps communities grow in ways that expand economic opportunity while protecting human health and the environment.

resource.resourcename: Smart Growth Self-Assessment for Rural Communities
resource.descriptiontext: The Smart Growth Self-Assessment for Rural Communities (2015) is a compilation of strategies, organized by 11 common "goal areas," that villages, towns, and small cities can use to evaluate their existing policies to create healthy, environmentally resilient, and economically robust places.
resource.commentstext: This self-assessment helps communities identify gaps in their policies, plans, codes, and zoning regulations by asking a series of "Yes" or "No" questions. All communities begin by completing the self-assessment's Revitalize Village and Town Centers section, which gives a baseline indication of smart growth development policies within the jurisdiction. It goes beyond regulatory issues to help communities take stock of their local initiatives, strategies, and plans.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Compilation of strategies organized by 11 common goal areas that communities can use to evaluate their policies.

resource.descriptiontext: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) was enacted by Congress in 1976 to protect human health and the environment from the potential hazards of waste disposal, conserve energy and natural resources, reduce the amount of waste generated, and ensure that wastes are managed in an environmentally sound manner.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource outlining Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA).

resource.descriptiontext: Mining and mineral processing facilities generate more toxic and hazardous waste than any other industrial sector, costing billions of dollars to address the public health and environmental threats to communities. EPA will reduce the risk of mining waste contamination of drinking water, rivers, and streams, and work to cleanup mining sites across the nation. Map of mineral processing facilities.

resource.descriptiontext:
"On June 16, 2009, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) joined together to help communities nationwide improve access to affordable housing, increase transportation options, and lower transportation costs while protecting the environment.
The Partnership for Sustainable Communities (PSC) works to coordinate federal housing, transportation, water, and other infrastructure investments to make neighborhoods more prosperous, allow people to live closer to jobs, save households time and money, and reduce pollution. The partnership agencies incorporate six principles of livability into federal funding programs, policies, and future legislative proposals."
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Designed to help communities nationwide improve access to affordable housing, increase transportation options, and lower transportation costs while protecting the environment.

It provides funding to community groups to contract their own technical adviser to interpret and explain technical reports, site conditions, and EPAs proposed cleanup proposals and decisions. An initial grant up to $50,000 is available to qualified community groups.

For example, it helps policymakers identify disaster types that are most common in a given country and have had significant historical impacts on specific human populations.

resource.descriptiontext: Approaches for reducing greenhouse gases from transportation include using low greenhouse gas fuels, improving vehicle technologies, reducing the number of vehicle miles traveled, and operating vehicles more efficiently. In combination, system approaches that combine these strategies can reduce transportation-related emissions significantly. This page gives a variety of different information regarding strategies and analysis to deal with transportation and climate change.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resources that provide information for reducing greenhouse gasses from transportation.

resource.descriptiontext: EPA and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) are taking coordinated steps to enable the production of a new generation of clean vehicles, through reduced greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and improved fuel use from on-road vehicles and engines, from the smallest cars to the largest trucks.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource providing information on transportation and climate regulation.

resource.shortdescriptiontext: Sustainable design in order to assist tribal communities in reducing the impact of construction on the environment, while protecting health, and culture of residents.

resource.descriptiontext: EPA's brownfields program provides direct funding for brownfields assessment, cleanup, revolving loans, and environmental job training. To facilitate the leveraging of public resources, EPA's Brownfields Program collaborates with other EPA programs, other federal partners, and state agencies to identify and make available resources that can be used for brownfields activities. In addition to direct brownfields funding, EPA also provides technical information on brownfields financing matters.

resource.descriptiontext: Every community and business faces some risk of climate-related disruptions to their operations. For some, it is not a question of "if" but "when" disruptions will occur. Anticipating potential problems and preparing to prevent or respond to them can make it easier to bounce back from disruptions.
resource.commentstext: East to use step by step guide to identify the problem, understand vulnerabilities, find alternatives, and eventually take action.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Toolkit for community and businesses to prepare for climate related disruptions.

resource.resourcename: Underground Storage Tanks (USTs) Laws and Regulations
resource.descriptiontext: A complete version of the law that governs underground storage tanks (USTs) is available in the U.S. Code, Title 42, Chapter 82, Subchapter IX. This law incorporates amendments to Subtitle I of the Solid Waste Disposal Act as well as the UST provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 and gives EPA the authority to regulate USTs.
resource.commentstext: Laws and Regulations.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Resource that provides information on a specific law that incorporates amendments to the Solid Waste Disposal Act as well as provisions to the Energy Policy Act of 2005.

resource.descriptiontext: Sustainability of waste management is key to providing an effective service that satisfies the needs of the end users. One pillar of sustainable solid waste management is strategic planning, and links to guidance are provided. Another pillar is cost analysis of solid waste options, and links to useful analytical tools are also provided. For financing, private sector involvement is a growing trend in solid waste management.

resource.descriptiontext: Adequate air ventilation is a vital part of ensuring good IAQ. Facilities and maintenance staff can use this checklist to help examine: outdoor air intakes, system cleanliness, outdoor, air supplies, air distribution, exhaust systems, quantity of outdoor air.

resource.primaryorganizationtext: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
resource.descriptiontext: The Verification Program evaluates the emission reduction performance and durability of specific retrofit technologies when submitted by manufacturers. The verification process includes a thorough technical review and tightly controlled testing to quantify levels of emission reductions and identify engine operating criteria and conditions that must be met for technologies to achieve those reductions.
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Evaluates the emission reduction performance and durability of specific retrofit technologies when submitted by manufacturers.

resource.resourcename: WEPPCAT: Online Tool for Assessing and Managing the Potential Impacts of Climate Change on Sediment Loading to Streams Using the Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP) Model.
resource.descriptiontext: WEPPCAT is an on-line tool that provides a flexible capability for creating user-determined climate change scenarios for assessing the potential impacts of climate change on sediment loading to streams using the USDA's Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP) Model. In combination with the existing capabilities of WEPP for assessing the effectiveness of management practices, WEPPCAT also can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of strategies for managing the impacts of climate change.ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â
resource.shortdescriptiontext: Tool that provides a flexible capability for creating user-determined climate change scenarios for assessing the potential impacts of climate change on sediment loading to streams.

resource.descriptiontext:
This website has an intuitive and user-friendly set of on-line process and practice guidlines, templates and decision support tools that will: - Simplify the development of consistent Total Asset Management Plans - Provide effective Implementation Guidelines for agencies to asses and drive meaningful improvements in asset management.
The users of this website will be: - Asset managers and operators - State and federal regulators - Appointed and elected officials - Engineering consultants - Managers and owners of contract operation firms.
resource.commentstext: A complete asset management system for small utilities. The toolset includes training, the system, and technical assistance.
